body: Hey @jrtechs I'll like to help here! How can I proceed?

@pepas24 Run the program, go to the website and see if there is anything you would like to change to make it look better. If you are unsure about any of your ideas, you can drop them in this issue and I can let you know what I think about it.
Thanks, I'll start to work on it!

Hi @jrtechs I made this mockup for the project, I want to know what do you think about this design before start with the markup.
[https://figma.fun/3kRC8q](https://figma.fun/3kRC8q)
@pepas24 That looks absolutely amazing! You have my permission to start working on this. If you want, feel free to break this up over a few pull requests.

Hi @jrtechs I advanced with home page and generator page you can take a look on my [fork](https://github.com/pepas24/github-graphs/tree/improvement/ui-redesign). Tomorrow I'll make a pull request. But some parts of other pages don't are well displayed because I removed some styles.
@pepas24 Sounds great.

@pepas24 I am so ecstatic that you worked on this project. It looks great!
![wowie](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13894625/67612382-2f17d680-f770-11e9-813b-30ccd2421aeb.png)

![wowie2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13894625/67612385-34752100-f770-11e9-8d30-03edd86f38cd.png)

The only thing I would suggest is that you update the organization view so that it has the same outlign/black box on the graph that the indivudial user has.

![wowie3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13894625/67612393-43f46a00-f770-11e9-9f8f-aa4d7d5427a0.png)

You can work on that in this PR or, we can merge this one and you can do it in a separate PR, I will leave that up to you.

Yes, I started the PR as draft because I haven't ended yet. But I think it is better to update all the ui in the same PR, because some styles don't aply well after my intervention. I'll updete the PR in a few days.

Hi @jrtechs since the past weekend I'm getting "user not exists" in all my requests, I noticed that some times works and others don't, I've checked out to master branch to test it and I've got the same error. Do you know what can be the problem? I can't finish the design that way :/

@pepas24 I know what the issue is. In the config.json file add the following line:

```  
"user": "jrtechs",
```

replace jrtechs with your github username.
Thanks that works!
@jrtechs I just finished the changes, please take a look and tell me what do you think.
@pepas24 I will look at this tonight.
@pepas24 I just looked at this and it looks absolutely amazing!!! I'm going to merge this now and upload it to the active server later tonight.
closed in #4

We currently just have basic configurations stored in the config.json file for the Github api, port, etc. What other environment variables are you referring to? Or, are you suggesting we change the config.js to a node .env environment file?
The gitignore file should be updated to prevent this from happening in the future.
hello my good sir, may I take this coding task ?

@jrtechs system environment variables, e.g. `FOO=BAR npm start` and `process.env`

Related (don't have to use):
https://www.npmjs.com/package/dotenv
https://www.npmjs.com/package/cross-env
@negreirosleo

I'm currently thinking about adding something along the lines of my open-source year in review. I am really inspired this year by these websites:
- https://rewind.youtube/
- https://spotify.me/en
- https://www.spotify.com/us/wrapped/

To start we could start focusing on generating graphs/collecting metrics/data. Later on, I want to go crazy and make the website look really slick. Here are my current ideas:

- number of commits throughout the year -- similar to the profile heatmap but a histogram
- contributions to repositories throughout the year. Similar to this graph in youtube rewind:
![rewindGraph](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13894625/70325560-41217600-1800-11ea-9da8-8a80c2fa7ad7.PNG)
- Show new organizations you joined and people you started following in a timeline graph or something.
- Use some metrics to determine your most contributed to the project in year x
- Use some metric to determine the repository you contributed to that had the most community impact.

Repository based metrics would be interesting. Just found this repository which used python to generate issues opened/closed chart:
https://github.com/keszybz/github-state

This is something that can probably easily be implemented in this project.
closed in #15

> Repository based metrics would be interesting. Just found this repository which used python to generate issues opened/closed chart:

To take it one step further, it would be cool to get insightful metrics such as average response time to issues opened by non-committers, the average lifespan of issues and pull requests (i.e. how many days/hours before an issue/PR is opened to closed)… if you want to do a 30 minute brainstorm chat over the winter break sometime, let me know. :slightly_smiling_face: 

An example of a Grimoire graph for such a thing:

![GrimoireLabs dashboard view showing the average response time to new GitHub issues](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4721034/70872860-b7e50e80-1f78-11ea-92a4-c0fa90fcc4cd.png)

@jwflory that would be great! Right now I'm trying to brainstorm/prioritize a list of 10ish things we can work on during the Spring semester. Working on multiple things/metrics would be a good way to scale this project for multiple contributors.
Do you have an example of a GitHub user to test this with?

@PeterMorganGH you can test it with this user: https://github-graphs.com/FriendsGraph.html?name=Balake-weasel

If you want to work on this that would be great! This is the file that needs to get changed:
https://github.com/jrtechs/github-graphs/blob/master/public/js/profileGen.js

Let me know if you have any other questions.
@jrtechs Thank you for providing the link. I have an idea of how to solve this issue and will see if it works.
If there is a value for `user.blog` the regular expression will check if it starts with "https://" or "http://". If the test fails, it will add "http://" to the front of the link.
